results.title: Strega Nonna
results.creator_credit: Weston Woods Studios and Gene Deitch
results.brief_description: Animated version of a traditional Calabrian tale retold and illustrated by Tomi de Paola. The story tells about a wise witch and her magic pasta pot. Winner of numerous awards. Suitable for primary school level.

results.title: Streetwise
results.brief_description: In this series of episodes that advise on self-defence, it is shown how women cope in difficult situations, and experts also comment on how to deal with threatening situations. Episode 1 - Self Defence; Episode 2 - Pick pockets; Episode 3 - Burglars; Episode 4 - Sexual Harassment.

results.title: Streets are for sharing
results.creator_credit: Peter Johnson, Film Australia and Greg Reading
results.brief_description: The film seeks to raise people’s awareness of the range of options available among the competing demands for use of our streets. Residents, pedestrians, cyclists, motorists, transporters, all expect the roadway to meet their demands. The solutions are discussed. Narrated by Colin Taylor and Pat Bishop. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Streetlife
results.creator_credit: Business Victoria: Dept of State Development and Image Link
results.brief_description: Four programs examine ways small communities have created employment. Program 1: Profiles the Beechworth Bakery as an example of a booming small business and tries to identify the factors which have made it successful. Program 2: Examines ecotourism in Kaikoura, New Zealand where the recognition of a natural feature has turned the town economy around. Program 3: Overviews Ouyen’s signage and streetscape projects which put the town on the tourist map. Program 4: Highlights Oamaru, New Zealand where the conservation of heritage buidings provided employment and attracted tourist dollars.

results.title: Street to the world
results.creator_credit: Leonard Forest, ONF | NFB and Louis-Georges Carrier
results.brief_description: A poetic study of the Montreal dock area and of a boy who escapes the monotony of his own backyard to while away fanciful hours at the great piers in wistful quest, exploring the wharves and watching ships pass up and down the broad St. Lawrence. (Award: Locarno.)

results.title: Street of shame = Akasen chitai [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Masaichi Nagata, Janus Films, Daiei Motion Picture Company and Kenji Mizoguchi
results.brief_description: The setting is a Tokyo brothel, ironically called Dreamland. The content is the thoughts, disappointments and aspirations of the occupants. This was Mizoguchi’s final film, and one in which he returned to his earlier theme of the exploitation of women throughout the ages. He does so by integrating the stories of five prostitutes which covers the roles of women as daughters, mothers and wives. Many believe that this film was pivotal in the 1957 decision to abolish prostitution in Japan. Cast includes Daisuke Kato, Machiko Kyo and Aiko Mimasu.

results.title: Street musique
results.brief_description: Visual improvisation on music performed by a popular group presented as sidewalk entertainers. The illustration is by a young film artist and animator who sees life with an amused and imaginative eye. His take-off point is the music, but his own beat is more boisterous than the musicians. He ranges from the most convoluted of abstractions to caricature of familiar rituals, including the bath. Photography by Pierre Provost, Cameron Gaul, Simon Leblanc. Music by Rick Scott, Dick Tarnoff, Rick Stone, Rick Watson, Jim Colby and Jon Van Arsdell. Sound by Roland Newton. (Five awards: including Oberhausen and Melbourne.)

results.title: Street life in Tehran
results.brief_description: A compilation of three short Iranian films all shot in Tehran and each purveying through its images, streetscapes of life and human behaviour at chosen moments in time. Independent and individual as each of these three films are, they also provide a juxtaposition to one another and an engaging focus on human interaction and reaction. “Deadtime” - An amusing look at what people do when they are stuck in congested city traffic with the traffic lights jammed on red. Close-up images of patient drivers, restless children, bored passengers and the various activities which take place to fill in the ticking minutes that appear to be turning into never-ending hours. No dialogue but contains street sounds and background music. “The White station” - In total contrast with “Deadtime”, this film presents a stark and isolated situation caused through a severe snow storm where a few brave and lonely souls are waiting for the arrival of the Tehran public transport system to pick them up. Evocative filming with just the sound of the wind and snow, interspersed with the occasional bird-life, simplistic and intriguing. No dialogue. “Tehran: the 25th hour” - On 29 November 1998 the return match of Iran and Australia for the World Cup 1998 was televised in Tehran live from Melbourne. Iran qualified and the quiet urban streets of Tehran soon transformed into mad scenes of jubilation and celebration, people everywhere of all ages joining in cheering and dancing, lining the streets on foot and in their cars. Two days later see this same mad passionate crowd contained in the Azadi Grand Stadium to welcome home their heroes - united and jubilant these fans are one. In Farsi with English subtitles.

results.title: Street kid
results.brief_description: In this short animation using both claymation and computer animation, a street kid is forced to survive in a harsh environment. He hunts through bins for food and is driven by his desperate circumstances to beg. After unsuccessfully begging he returns to the alley and is approached by a man who appears to care but has dubious intentions, pushing drugs onto the young boy.

results.title: Street Hero
results.brief_description: Vince Colosimo is a young guy living in a world of drugs, illegal gambling and cruising cop cars. The only thing that keeps him above the mire of petty criminals is his music. The guy’s a drummer in a school band. He’s got the chance to improve his status in the local “Mafia” and they’re pushing for a decision, “Vinnie, you either go it alone, or you join us and get on in the world.”
